title: Headstock Bearing Check/Adjustment

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Raise and support the front of the motorcycle.
Move the handlebars from lock to lock whilst checking for signs of tightness.
Hold the lower end of the front forks as illustrated and 'rock' with a front-to-rear motion. If free play can be detected, the headstock bearings require adjustment.
Raise and support the front of the motorcycle.
Loosen the upper yoke clamp bolts.
If the lower yoke fixings are also loosened, the forks will no longer support the weight of the motorcycle.
Do not loosen the lower yoke fixings as, in this condition, the motorcycle could topple over causing damage and/or risk of injury.
Always protect the upper yoke from damage or scratches.
Failure to protect the upper yoke may cause damage to the surface(s).
Damage or scratches to polished surfaces may cause irreparable damage to the motorcycle.
Protect the area around the upper yoke top nut using a protective tape.
Release the upper yoke top nut and remove the upper yoke.
Ease the upper yoke from the forks and support while detached.
When adjusting the bearing free-play, make sure that the threaded part of the stem is free from grease.
Adjust the bearing free-play as follows, all using
Remove the locknut and tab washer.
Fit the adjuster nut and tighten clockwise to
Loosen the torque adjuster nut fully.
Tighten the adjuster nut clockwise to
Fit the rubber washer and push it down until it is fully in contact with the adjuster nut.
Fit the locknut and tighten clockwise by hand until it comes into contact with the rubber washer
Turn the locknut clockwise until the castellated end aligns with the adjuster nut castlellations.
Fit the tabbed washer through the locknut and adjuster nuts.

It is essential that the adjuster nut is not over-tightened. If the adjuster is over tightened it will cause a preload on the headstock bearings. This will introduce tight steering, which could cause loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
Refit the upper yoke to the forks.
Tighten the upper yoke clamp bolts to

Move the handlebars to left and right full lock while checking that the brake hose, clutch cable and electrical harnesses do not bind or that the steering feels tight or difficult to turn. A hose, cable or harness that binds, or steering that is tight/difficult to turn will restrict the steering and may cause loss of control and an accident.

Check for correct operation of the front brake, clutch and twist grip. Check that the brake hose, clutch cable and electrical harnesses do not bind or restrict the steering when the handlebars are turned from lock-to-lock. Rectify as necessary.
Lower the motorcycle to the ground and park it on the side stand.
